slides.title: The U.S. Business Environment
content: Businesses encounter economic, political, technological, and cultural forces.
Effective managers understand these forces and capitalize on opportunities.
This understanding allows appreciation for the manager’s role and challenges.
It will provide a better knowledge of why prices go up and down.
This chapter introduces core concepts of profit, loss, and the external environment.
slides.script: Welcome to Chapter 1, 'The U.S. Business Environment'.  In this chapter, we'll be exploring the various forces that shape the way businesses operate. We'll see how economic, political, technological, and cultural factors impact businesses. Understanding these forces helps managers make better decisions and capitalize on opportunities while navigating the challenges in the external environments. We'll also introduce key concepts like profit and loss, and of course, it helps you understand the business decisions that affect you everyday.

slides.title: Business and the External Environment
content: Businesses are organizations that provide goods or services for profit.
Profits are the rewards for risking time and money in a business.
Businesses must consider consumer demand when pursuing profits.
Enterprising individuals identify and capitalize on business opportunities.
A healthy business climate improves the overall standard of living.
slides.script: Now let's look at the basics of business. We’ll define what a business is, and why the profit motive is so important. We’ll discuss how businesses need to respond to consumer demand. The freedom to pursue profits is an incentive for entrepreneurs to identify needs and create products or services. Finally, we’ll explore how a thriving business sector benefits society as a whole.

slides.title: Dimensions of the External Environment
content: The external environment consists of factors outside the organization's boundaries.
These factors significantly impact an organization’s success or failure.
Key dimensions: domestic, global, technological, political-legal, sociocultural, economic.
Businesses can both be influenced by and influence their environments.
slides.script: This slide introduces the key dimensions of the external environment that all businesses must consider. Managers must have a strong grasp of these factors. We’ll examine the domestic, global, technological, political-legal, sociocultural, and economic environments that shape the business landscape. Note that all the environmental factors affect businesses and businesses also affect all the environmental factors.

slides.title: Economic Systems: Factors of Production
content: An economic system allocates resources among its citizens and organizations.
Factors of production: labor, capital, entrepreneurs, physical resources, information.
Labor includes the physical and intellectual contributions of workers.
Capital encompasses the financial resources required to operate a business.
Entrepreneurs accept the risks and opportunities of creating a new business.
Physical resources are the tangible things used by the organization.
Information resources include data and knowledge used by businesses.
slides.script: This slide outlines the basic factors of production that every economic system needs to manage. These resources are crucial for producing goods and services. We’ll examine the role of labor, capital, entrepreneurs, physical resources, and information resources in creating a successful economy. Understanding these factors is essential for understanding how different economic systems operate.

slides.title: Types of Economic Systems
content: Market economy: Individuals control production and allocation through supply and demand.
Planned economy: Government controls factors of production and makes allocation decisions.
Mixed market economy: Combines elements of both planned and market economies.
Privatization converts government enterprises into privately owned companies.
Socialism: The government owns and operates major industries.
slides.script: This slide explores the different types of economic systems that exist in the world. We’ll compare market economies, where supply and demand dictate production, with planned economies, where the government controls the means of production. Most countries today operate under a mixed market economy, incorporating elements of both. We'll discuss the process of privatization and the economic theory of socialism in this context.

slides.title: Market Economics: Demand and Supply
content: Decisions about buying and selling are determined by demand and supply.
Law of demand: Price drops, demand increases; price increases, demand decreases.
Law of supply: Price rises, supply increases; price drops, supply decreases.
A demand and supply schedule reveals relationships at different price levels.
Market price (equilibrium price): Quantity demanded equals the quantity supplied.
slides.script: Now we’ll delve into the core principles of market economies – supply and demand. We’ll examine how these forces determine what is bought and sold. We’ll review the laws of demand and supply, and see how they interact to create an equilibrium price in the market. Understanding these concepts is crucial for understanding how resources are distributed and how businesses make pricing decisions.

slides.title: Market Economics: Private Enterprise
content: Private enterprise system: Individuals pursue interests with minimal government restriction.
Requires: private property rights, freedom of choice, profits, competition.
Private property rights: Individuals own the resources used to create wealth.
Freedom of choice: Sell labor to any employer; choose which products to buy.
Profits: Leads people to entrepreneurship and influence what to produce.
Competition: Motivates businesses to operate efficiently.
slides.script: This slide introduces the concept of private enterprise, which is central to market economies. We’ll explore the four key elements: private property rights, freedom of choice, profits, and competition. We'll also see how these elements combine to create a dynamic and innovative business environment.

slides.title: Degrees of Competition
content: Perfect competition: Many small firms producing identical products.
Monopolistic competition: Many sellers trying to differentiate their products.
Oligopoly: A few large sellers with the power to influence prices.
Monopoly: One producer controlling the prices of its products.
slides.script: This slide explores the different degrees of competition that exist within a market economy. We'll discuss perfect competition, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and monopoly, and examine the characteristics that define each type of market. Understanding these different forms of competition helps businesses strategize and navigate their respective industries.

slides.title: Economic Indicators: Measuring Performance
content: Economic indicators assess whether an economic system is strengthening or weakening.
Indicators include: economic growth, aggregate output, and standard of living.
GDP reflects all goods and services produced by a national economy.
GDP per capita reflects a nation’s standard of living.
Real GDP:  Adjusted for changes in currency values and price changes.
slides.script: This slide introduces the concept of economic indicators, which are key statistics that help us gauge the health of an economy. We’ll examine several important indicators, including economic growth, aggregate output, and standard of living. We’ll also discuss how gross domestic product, or GDP, is used to measure the economic well-being of a nation.

slides.title: Measuring Economic Growth
content: Productivity: A measure comparing production output and resources to create.
Standard of living improves only through increased productivity.
Balance of Trade: Value of exports minus value of imports.
National Debt: Money the government owes to creditors.
slides.script: This slide focuses on the role of productivity, balance of trade, and national debt in measuring economic growth. We’ll see how increasing productivity leads to a higher standard of living. We’ll also explore how trade deficits and the national debt can affect economic growth and stability.

slides.title: Economic Stability: Keeping Things Balanced
content: Stability: Money and quantity of goods and services grow at the same rate.
Inflation: Widespread price increases occur in the economic system.
Deflation: Widespread price cuts occur in the economic system.
Consumer Price Index (CPI): Measures the prices of typical products.
Unemployment: A level of joblessness among people actively seeking work.
slides.script: Now let's look at economic stability. We'll define stability, and then examine the concepts of inflation, deflation, the Consumer Price Index or CPI, and unemployment. Understanding these concepts is crucial for understanding the dynamics of a stable and healthy economy.

slides.title: Managing the U.S. Economy
content: Fiscal policies: How the government collects and spends its revenues.
Monetary policies: Managing the nation’s money supply and interest rates.
Goal: To smooth out fluctuations in output and unemployment.
Goal: To stabilize prices.
slides.script: Now we’ll examine how the U.S. government attempts to manage the economy. We'll discuss fiscal policies, which involve government spending and revenue collection. And we’ll explore monetary policies, which are focused on controlling the money supply and interest rates. The goal of these interventions is to stabilize the economy and promote growth while keeping prices stable.
